## Motivating Task ğŸ“‹

After taking our course, your boss asks you to give a **presentation** on two possible applications of the skills learned to the company/your work. You want to use LLMs for some **brainstorming help**. ğŸ§ 

**Links we'll use:**

- [AI for Work & Research Course](https://thegraphcourses.org/aiw/) ğŸ“š
- [Sample Resume](https://the-graph-courses.github.io/misc_public/taylor_helper.html) (Taylor Helper) ğŸ“„
- [ICON Company Overview](https://www.iconplc.com/about/icon-glance) ğŸ¢  

## A. Give Good Context ğŸ”§

::: {.incremental}

1. **Start fresh sessions** for different topics to keep context clear ğŸ”„
   <!-- This helps keep the context clear and focused -->

2. Use a good **clipboard manager** for managing context ğŸ“‹. [Windows](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mOXDyrEwjK0), [Mac](https://maccy.app/)
   <!-- A clipboard manager helps efficiently handle multiple pieces of text and context -->

3. **Shift + Enter** to go to new line â†µ
   <!-- This keyboard shortcut helps maintain clean formatting in prompts -->

4. **Edit** instead of extending the conversation to fix mistakes âœï¸
   <!-- Keeps conversations concise and maintains context -->

5. To copy in text that has links, first paste into <span class="highlight">Google Docs</span>, then copy as markdown ğŸ”—
   <!-- Converts links to markdown format for better compatibility -->

6. Let the model **ask clarifying questions** â“
   <!-- Ensures all requirements are understood before proceeding -->


:::

::: {.notes}
Example workflow that we will use to demonstrate points 1 to 4:
- After taking our course, your boss asks you to give a presentation on two possible applications of the skills learned to the company/your work.
- We'll demo how you can copy the AI course description, company description, and CV
- Ask the model to suggest applications of the skills
- Use clipboard manager to efficiently manage all copied content 
- Use the edit button to fix mistakes
:::

## B. Iterate ğŸ¯

::: {.incremental}

1. **Try again** - first attempt isn't always best ğŸ”„

2. Ask for a <span class="highlight">ridiculous number</span> of suggestions ğŸ’¯
   <!-- 100! Why not? Then we pick one that works -->

3. Ask for **multiple styles** ğŸ¨  
   <!-- Academic style, Business style, Conversational style -->

4. Ask for **multiple formats** ğŸ“‹
   <!-- HTML overview, HTML slides, PPTX, etc. -->

5. Ask **many models** ğŸ¤–
   <!-- Use openrouter or go to each model's website -->

6. Ask the model to **critique itself** ğŸ”
   <!-- Self-review can lead to significant improvements -->

:::

## C. Verify âœ…

- **Don't trust** that the model is competent at a class of tasks just because it claims to be - <span class="highlight">always verify first</span> ğŸš¨

<!-- Models can be overconfident and hallucinate information. Always verify capabilities before relying on them -->

::: {.fragment}
**Example:**

- Ask DeepSeek (no search turned on): *"Suggest some papers from 2024 I should read to write a discussion for this [paper](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-25946-0) ..."*

- Gets lots of **hallucinated papers** ğŸš«
:::

- <span class="highlight">Try things</span> before assuming the model can't do it âœ¨
